# Sound plurals

## Introduction

Arabic uses the plural for nouns in number three and higher. The formation and use of plurals in Arabic can be somewhat complicated. Furthermore, there is sometimes more than one way to use plurals. In this chapter we will explain the most common usage to keep things as simple as possible.

English regularly forms the plural by adding the plural ending "s" to the end of a singular noun. For example:

| Singular | Plural |
|:-----------|:-----------|
| book       | books      |
| house      | houses     |
| boy        | boys       |
| girl       | girls      |

Arabic also forms some plurals by adding plural endings to to the singular noun. This kind of plural is call a _sound_ plural because the singular noun is kept more or less sound (intact) when adding the plural ending.

Arabic has two sound plurals:

1. The [Un]{.trn} plural.
2. The [At]{.trn} plural.

We will describe each of them in detail.

## The [Un]{.trn} plural

The [Un]{.trn} plural is formed by adding the ending [ـُونَ]{.ar} [Una]{.trn} to the singular noun when it is in the u-state, and [ـِينَ]{.ar} [Ina]{.trn} when the noun is in the a-state or i-state. For convenience, we will call it the "[Un]{.trn} plural" instead of the "[Una]{.trn}/[Ina]{.trn} plural".

| State | a (male) teacher | (male) teachers |
|:-----------|:-------------|:-------------|
| u-state |[مُعَلِّمٌ]{.ar} [mueallimun]{.trn} | [مُعَلِّمُونَ]{.ar} [mueallimUna]{.trn}| 
| a-state |[مُعَلِّمًا]{.ar} [muealliman]{.trn}| [مُعَلِّمِينَ]{.ar} [mueallimIna]{.trn} | 
| i-state |[مُعَلِّمٍ]{.ar} [mueallimin]{.trn} | [مُعَلِّمِينَ]{.ar} [mueallimIna]{.trn} |

Note that there are no [n]{.trn} marks for the [Un]{.trn} plural. Definite plural nouns are also formed in the same way:

| State | the (male) teacher | the (male) teachers |
|:-----------|:-------------|:-------------|
| u-state | [ٱَلْمُعَلِّمُ]{.ar} [Ealmueallimu]{.trn}| [ٱَلْمُعَلِّمُونَ]{.ar} [EalmueallimUna]{.trn}
| a-state | [ٱَلْمُعَلِّمَ]{.ar} [Ealmueallima]{.trn}| [ٱَلْمُعَلِّمِينَ]{.ar} [EalmueallimIna]{.trn}  
| i-state |[ٱَلْمُعَلِّمِ]{.ar} [Ealmueallimi]{.trn} | [ٱَلْمُعَلِّمِينَ]{.ar} [EalmueallimIna]{.trn}

Except for very few exceptions, the [Un]{.trn} plural is used only for male rational beings (humans, angels, and jinn). Of these exceptions, the word [سَنَةٌ]{.ar} [sanatun]{.trn} "a year" is the most common. It is pluralized as [سِنُونَ]{.ar} [sinUna]{.trn} in the u-state and [سِنِينَ]{.ar} [sinIna]{.trn} in the a-state and i-state.

## The [At]{.trn} plural

The [At]{.trn} plural is formed by adding the ending [ـَاتٌ]{.ar} [Atun]{.trn} to the indefinite singular noun when it is in the u-state, and [ـَاتٍ]{.ar} [Atin]{.trn} when the noun is in the a-state or i-state.

| State | an animal | animals
|:-----------|:-------------|:-------------|
| u-state | [حَيَوَانٌ]{.ar} [HayawAnun]{.trn}  | [حَيَوَانَاتٌ]{.ar} [HayawAnAtun]{.trn}
| a-state | [حَيَوَانًا]{.ar} [HayawAnan]{.trn} | [حَيَوَانَاتٍ]{.ar} [HayawAnAtin]{.trn} 
| i-state |[حَيَوَانٍ]{.ar} [HayawAnin]{.trn}   | [حَيَوَانَاتٍ]{.ar} [HayawAnAtin]{.trn} 

Note that there _are_ [n]{.trn} marks for the [At]{.trn} plural. Definite plural nouns are also formed in the same way but they won't have [n]{.trn} marks:

| State | the animal | the animals
|:-----------|:-------------|:-------------|
| u-state | [ٱَلْحَيَوَانُ]{.ar} [EalHayawAnu]{.trn}| [ٱَلْحَيَوَانَاتُ]{.ar} [EalHayawAnAtu]{.trn}
| a-state | [ٱَلْحَيَوَانَ]{.ar} [EalHayawAna]{.trn}| [ٱَلْحَيَوَانَاتِ]{.ar} [EalHayawAnAti]{.trn}  
| i-state |[ٱَلْحَيَوَانِ]{.ar} [EalHayawAni]{.trn} | [ٱَلْحَيَوَانَاتِ]{.ar} [EalHayawAnAti]{.trn}

If a noun ends with a looped [tAE]{.trn} [ة]{.ar}, then it is removed before appending the [At]{.trn} plural ending:

| State | a (female) teacher | (female) teachers |
|:-----------|:-------------|:-------------|
| u-state | [مُعَلِّمَةٌ]{.ar} [mueallimatun]{.trn}| [مُعَلِّمَاتٌ]{.ar} [mueallimAtun]{.trn}
| a-state | [مُعَلِّمَةً]{.ar} [mueallimatan]{.trn}| [مُعَلِّمَاتٍ]{.ar} [mueallimAtin]{.trn}  
| i-state |[مُعَلِّمَةٍ]{.ar} [mueallimatin]{.trn} | [مُعَلِّمَاتٍ]{.ar} [mueallimAtin]{.trn} 

### The [At]{.trn} plural for words ending with [اء]{.ar}

If a noun ends with an [اء]{.ar} then the [hamzah]{.trn} may either be retained or get converted to a [و]{.ar} when forming the [At]{.trn} plural. This is done based on the same rules as for the dual which we explained in the previous chapter.

Thus,

+ [صَفْرَاءُ]{.ar} [SafrAE]{.trn} (root: [صفر]{.arroot}) becomes [صَفْرَاوَاتٌ]{.ar} [SafrAwAtun]{.trn}.
+ [صَحْرَاءُ]{.ar} [SaHrAE]{.trn} (root: [صحر]{.arroot}) becomes [صَحْرَاوَاتٌ]{.ar} [SaHrAwAtun]{.trn}.
+ [إِبْطًاءٌ]{.ar} [EibTAEun]{.trn} (root: [بطء]{.arroot}) becomes [إِبْطَاءَاتٌ]{.ar} [EibTAEAtun]{.trn}.
+ [سَمَاءٌ]{.ar} [samAEun]{.trn} (root: [سمو]{.arroot}) becomes [سَمَاءَاتٌ]{.ar} [samAEAtun]{.trn} or [سَمَاوَاتٌ]{.ar} [samAwAtun]{.trn}.

### The [At]{.trn} plural for words ending with [يٰ]{.ar}

If a noun ends with [ىٰ]{.ar}, then whether the [ىٰ]{.ar} is a feminine marker or not, it becomes a [yAE]{.trn} with an [a]{.trn}-mark [يَ]{.ar} when forming the [At]{.trn} plural. For example,  

+ [حُبَارَىٰ]{.ar} [HubArA]{.trn} becomes [حُبَارَيَاتٌ]{.ar} [HubArayAtun]{.trn}.

### Non-descriptive nouns of the pattern [فَُِعْل]{.ar} and [فَُِعْلَة]{.ar}

If a non-descriptive noun is of the pattern [فَعْل]{.ar} [fa3l]{.trn} or [فَعْلَة]{.ar} [fa3lah]{.trn}, and the middle letter is not [و]{.ar} or [ي]{.ar}, then the rest-mark on the middle letter will be converted to an [a]{.trn}-mark when forming the [At]{.trn} plural. Therefore, 

+ [نَحْلَة]{.ar} [naHlah]{.trn} becomes [نَحَلَات]{.ar} [naHalAt]{.trn}, not [نَحْلَات]{.ar} [naHlAt]{.trn}.

If a non-descriptive noun is of the pattern [فِعْل]{.ar} [fi3l]{.trn}, [فِعْلَة]{.ar} [fi3lah]{.trn}, [فُعْل]{.ar} [fu3l]{.trn}, or [فُعْلَة]{.ar} [fu3lah]{.trn}, and the middle letter is not [و]{.ar} or [ي]{.ar}, then the rest-mark on the middle letter can either:

  i.   be retained,
  ii.  be converted to an [a]{.trn} mark, or
  iii. be converted to the vowel mark on the first letter.

Thus,

+ [ظُلْمَة]{.ar} can become either [ظُلْمَات]{.ar} [PulmAt]{.trn} or [ظُلَمَات]{.ar} [PulamAt]{.trn}, or [ظُلُمَات]{.ar} [PulumAt]{.trn}.
+ [كِسْرَة]{.ar} can become either [كِسْرَات]{.ar} [kisrAt]{.trn} or [كِسَرَات]{.ar} [kisarAt]{.trn}, or [كِسِرَات]{.ar} [kisirAt]{.trn}.

Note that this is only true for non-descriptive nouns. Descriptive nouns will retain the rest-mark when forming the [At]{.trn} plural. So [صَعْب]{.ar} [Saeb]{.trn} and [صَعْبَة]{.ar} [Saebah]{.trn} become only [صَعْبَات]{.ar} [SaebAt]{.trn}, not [صَعَبَات]{.ar} [SaeabAt]{.trn}.

The [At]{.trn} is used for female human beings and also for many other nouns.

The female teachers are in the school.

## Plurals with descriptive nouns

In the pluralization of descriptive nouns Arabic distinguishes between rational beings (humans, angels, and jinn) and non-rational beings (animals, inanimate objects, abstract concepts, etc.).

When a descriptive noun is describing a plural noun denoting rational beings, then the descriptive noun will be pluralized. For example,

[ٱَلْمُعَلِّمُونَ طَيِّبُونَ.]{.ar}  
[EalmueallimUna TayyibUna]{.trn}  
"The male teachers are good."

[كَانَتِ ٱلْجَارِيَاتُ ٱلطَّوِيلَاتُ سَرِيعَاتٍ.]{.ar}  
[kAnati -ljAriyAtu -TTawIlAtu sarIeAtin]{.trn}  
"The tall girls were fast."

When a descriptive noun is describing a plural noun denoting non-rational beings, either as the describer in a noun-phrase, or in the information of a sentence, then the descriptive noun will typically not be pluralized. The feminine singular descriptive noun is used instead, even if the described noun is masculine. For example,

[حَيَوَانَاتٌ وَحْشَةٌ]{.ar}  
[HayawAnatun waHcatun]{.trn}  
"wild animals"

[ٱَلسِّنُونَ ٱلصَّعْبَةُ]{.ar}  
[EassinUna -SSaebatu]{.trn}  
"the difficult years"

[ٱَلْحَيَوَانَاتُ ٱلْوَحْشَةُ كَبِيرَةٌ.]{.ar}  
[EalHayawAnAtu -lwaHcatu kabIratun]{.trn}  
"The wild animals are big."

[كَانَتِ ٱلسِّنُونَ ٱلصَّعْبَةُ طَوِيلَةً.]{.ar}  
[kAnati -ssinUna -SSaebatu TawIlatan]{.trn}  
"The difficult years were long."

This is done even if the desrciptive noun in the information of the sentence is definite. For example,

[كَانَتِ ٱلسِّنُونَ ٱلصَّعْبَةُ ٱلطَّوِيلَةَ.]{.ar}  
[kAnati -ssinUna -SSaebatu -TTawIlata]{.trn}  
"The difficult years were the long ones."

Note, however, that when a descriptive noun denoting plural non-rational beings is not the describer in a noun-phrase, or is not the information of a sentence, then it will be pluralized. But remember that the [Un]{.trn} plural is only used for male human beings. So the [At]{.trn} plural will be used, even if the descriptive noun refers to a masculine object. For example,

[ٱَلْحَيَوَانَاتُ كَبِيرَةٌ وَصَغِيرَةٌ. ٱَلْكَبِيرَاتُ قَوِيَّةٌ.]{.ar}  
[EalHayawAnatu kabIratun wa SagIratun. EalkabIrAtu qawiyyatun]{.trn}  
"The animals are big and small. The big ones are strong."

In the example above, in the first sentence the descriptive nouns [كَبِيرَةٌ]{.ar} [kabIratun]{.trn} "big" and [صَغِيرَةٌ]{.ar} [SagIratun]{.trn} "small" are in the feminine singular because they are the information of the sentence and are describing the non-human plural described noun [ٱَلْحَيَوَانَاتُ]{.ar} [EalHayawAnAtu]{.trn} "the animals".

But in the second sentence, the descriptive noun 
[ٱَلْكَبِيرَاتُ]{.ar} [EalkabIrAtu]{.trn} "the big ones"
is the subject of the sentence. It is used as a regular noun so it is pluralized with the [At]{.trn} plural. 

It is also the described noun for the descriptive noun [قَوِيَّةٌ]{.ar} [qawiyyatun]{.trn} "strong". [قَوِيَّةٌ]{.ar} is feminine singular because it is the information of the sentence and is describing the non-human plural described noun [ٱَلْكَبِيرَاتُ]{.ar} [EalkabIrAtu]{.trn} "the big ones".

## Remove 

However, English also has an _irregular_ plural for a few common nouns:

| Singular | Plural |
|:-----------|:-----------|
| man        | men        |
| woman      | women      |
| child      | children   |
| mouse      | mice       |

Arabic also has two types of plurals:

1. Sound plurals: The singular noun is kept sound (intact) and a plural ending is added to the singular noun just like the English "s".
2. Broken plurals: The singular noun is not kept intact but is "broken up" in forming the plural.

In this chapter we will introduce sound plurals.

Arabic too forms some plurals by appending one of two endings to the singular nouns. Examples:

| Singular | Plural |
|:-----------|:-----------|
| [مُعَلِّمٌ]{.ar} [mueallimun]{.trn} "a male teacher"       | [مُعَلِّمُونَ]{.ar} [mueallimUna]{.trn} "male teachers"       |
| [مُعَلِّمَةٌ]{.ar} [mueallimatun]{.trn} "a female teacher"       | [مُعَلِّمَاتٌ]{.ar} [mueallimAtun]{.trn} "female teachers"       |
